bboxes.raw_text:
E. D. Eddington, AZ, of 1909
E. Adams, has been placed on
six months probation after being
credited with l9 months of time
served in Arizona State Prison
on a jury conviction of assault
with deadly weapon.


Eddington pleaded guilty to re-
sisting arrest, and the county
attorney S office dropped the as
sault with a deadly weapon charge
on which the Arizona Supreme
Court has ordered new trial.


The defendant had been &C
cused of shooting Arnold James
Bishop, IS, on May 8, 1862, as
they argued outside a tavern at
1914 E. Washington. Bishop was
hospitalized in critical condition
but recovered.

PINE BLUFF, Ark. The mar
riage of two SNCC workers here
has been called ga deliberate,
direct dis-service to the white
and colored people of our state
by the State Attorney General.


Attorney General Bruce Ben
net said of the newly-wed: &C..
....neither of these people works
for living, but are paid by the
Student Non-violent Coordinating
Committee, which is a trouble
making organization


The two--Mr. and Mrs. Will
liam Hansen--were married in
Cincinnati, Ohio, on October IL.
Hansen is white and Mrs. Han
sen, the former Ruthie Buffing-
ton, is Negro.


Inter-racial weddings are IL
legal in Arkansas.


Hansen has been in Pine Bluff
since December, 1862. He helped
form the Pine Bluff Movement,
and involved students at Arkan-
sas AMIN in sit-in demonstra-
tons. Mrs. Hansen, one of the
students, was, with ten others,
suspended from school on Feb
ruary Is.


Violation of the state law S
against mixed marriages Is pun
ishable by a fine and a one
year Jail sentence.

PHILADELPHIA The NAACP
branch here called for picket
ing of the proposed football game
between Mississippi State and
North Carolina State to be played
in the Liberty Bowl here.


In calling for this action, Cecil
B. Moore, president of the branch
pointed to the fact that Negro cit
liens, whose taxes help support
the stadium, are denied admis-
sion to Mississippi State and are
unwelcomed at either institution.


In addition to its implications
for civil rights and race relations
the Mississippi State VS.. North
Carolina State game has no draw
ing power in Philadelphia, he
added.

WASHINGTON-The civil rights
march on Washington last Aug.
% cost the taxpayers $805 900
Rep. George Huddleston Jr., D.
Ala, reported.


He asked Comptroller General
Joseph Campbell the day of the
march for an account of its cost
to the government.


Campbell has reported to him
that "out-of-pocket costs and
diversion costs to the District
of Columbia government and the
Department of Defense totaled
$225, 900, Huddlestone said.


elm addition, administrative
leave costs to government agen-
cies in the area took another
$55O,0OO from our taxpayers,
bringing the estimated total to
$8O5, OOO," Huddleston said.


"This figure of $805, 900 does
not include some SIS, 900 for food
provided to policemen on duty
which the district refused to pay
for because it was spoiled: cost
incurred by the district in the
amount of $4,000 in the value
of overtime work performed by
uniformed personnel on their
regular workday, for which no
compensation is authorized by
law or the estimated amount of
losses of sales tax revenue to the
district of $4,000 to $45, 900
and parking meter revenue los
ses estimated at $780," Hud-
dleston said.

pupils of Miss Melissa Cayton honored
Christmas party last week.


From left George Washington Christina and Zebra Hankn
Barbara Golfer Frances Carraway and Robert Carraway
Miss Cayton shown a the back to the left.
The party held al home at 5044 S. 81 Place.

NAACP TOLEAD


BOWL PICkETING
full articles.article:

branch here called for picket
